context: Prior to the Reformation, the Polish nobility were mostly either <a0_0>Roman Catholic or Orthodox<a0_0/> with a small group of <a1_0>Muslims<a1_0/>. Many families, however, soon adopted the Reformed faiths. After the Counter-Reformation, when the Roman Catholic Church regained power in Poland, <a3_0>the nobility became almost exclusively Catholic<a3_0/>, despite the fact that Roman Catholicism was not the majority religion in Commonwealth (the Catholic and Orthodox churches each accounted for some 40% of all citizens population, with the remaining 20% being <a4_0>Jews<a4_0/> or members of Protestant denominations). In the 18th century, many followers of Jacob Frank joined the ranks of Jewish-descended Polish gentry. Although Jewish religion wasn't usually a pretext to block or deprive of noble status, some laws favoured religious conversion from Judaism to Christianity (see: Neophyte) by rewarding it with <a2_0>ennoblement<a2_0/>.
